intro: Leucopogon acutifolius, commonly known as the narrow-leaved heath, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and small, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in acidic, well-drained soils in open woodlands or pine flatwoods. Its leaves are narrow and leathery, with a distinctive acuminate tip, and it produces clusters of white or pale pink flowers in late spring. Leucopogon acutifolius is often found in wetland habitats and is adapted to tolerate periodic flooding.
